diagnosis.primary: Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCCa) of the Anal Canal
diagnosis.location: Anal Canal, extending to involve anal margin
diagnosis.symptomsAtPresentation: Rectal bleeding, anal pain, palpable lump in right groin.

treatmentPlan.modality: External Beam Radiation Therapy (EBRT) with concurrent Chemotherapy
treatmentPlan.targetVolumeSummary: PTV_Elective (Pelvic/Inguinal Nodes), PTV_Primary (Primary Tumor), PTV_Node (Positive Node)
medications: Topical skin care (e.g., Silver sulfadiazine, Domeboro soaks) for perineal dermatitis

ctSimulation.setupInstructions: Patient positioned prone on a belly board to displace small bowel. Arms up on wing board or to sides per comfort. SAD setup.
ctSimulation.immobilization: Belly board, prone pillow, ankle immobilization.
ctSimulation.referenceMarks: 3-point tattoos at isocenter projections (AP and bilateral laterals).
ctSimulation.contrastUsed: IV and/or oral contrast may be used per institutional protocol.
ctSimulation.ctNotes: CT acquired in prone position for VMAT planning. Fused with diagnostic PET/MRI for target delineation.

dosimetry.constraints: Fem Head Max < 45 Gy; Bladder V40Gy < 50%; Bowel Max < 54 Gy; Genitalia Mean < 30 Gy
dosimetry.planNotes: Definitive chemoradiation VMAT. Prone setup selected for small bowel and genitalia sparing.

fractions.setupNotes: Daily CBCT IGRT. Patient setup in prone position on belly board. Setup consistent.
fractions.sideEffects: Significant perineal skin irritation (Grade 2 dermatitis), diarrhea (Grade 2).
fractions.notes: Managing with Loperamide, Silvadene cream, and sitz baths. Prone position makes skin checks more challenging but is maintained.

imagingAndReports.summary: Irregular thickening anal canal. Enlarged R inguinal node (1.7 cm).
Confirms T2 primary anal canal tumor and enlarged R inguinal node.
Hypermetabolic anal primary (SUV 11.0) and R inguinal node (SUV 8.5). No other FDG-avid disease.

imagingAndReports.type: Fine Needle Aspiration (FNA) Report - R Groin

imagingAndReports.summary: CT acquired prone on belly board for IMRT/VMAT planning.

progressNotes.author: Dr. Frank Miller (ColoRectal)
progressNotes.summary: Pt referred for rectal bleeding. Exam shows anal canal mass. Imaging/PET confirm T2 tumor with positive R inguinal node. Biopsy -> SCCa. FNA groin node +. Refer to Med Onc / Rad Onc for definitive chemoradiation.

progressNotes.author: Dr. Garcia/Dr. Clark
progressNotes.summary: Case reviewed. Plan for definitive chemoradiation per Nigro protocol (MMC/5FU + RT to 58Gy via VMAT). Prone setup chosen for potential small bowel and genitalia sparing. Discussed toxicities (hematologic, GI, skin). Pt agrees.

progressNotes.author: Nursing
progressNotes.summary: Patient educated on MMC/5FU regimen (infusional pump for 5FU), RT schedule (prone setup), expected side effects, skin care protocol, diet modifications.

progressNotes.author: Dr. Patricia Clark (Rad Onc)
progressNotes.summary: Pt c/o significant perineal skin irritation/pain (Grade 2 dermatitis), diarrhea (Grade 2). Managing with Loperamide, Silvadene, sitz baths. Labs show low counts, discussed w/ Dr. Garcia. Continue RT. Emphasize supportive care.

progressNotes.author: Dr. Robert Garcia (Med Onc)
progressNotes.summary: Pt recovering from cycle 1 toxicities. Skin improving slowly. Diarrhea controlled. CBC recovered adequately. Proceed with Cycle 2 MMC/5FU starting Day 29 of RT.

patientEducation.goalsDiscussed: Definitive (curative) treatment to eradicate the anal cancer without the need for major surgery (colostomy).
patientEducation.sideEffectsReviewed: Acute: Severe skin reaction in the perineal/groin area (dermatitis), diarrhea, fatigue, low blood counts (from chemo), mouth sores, nausea. Late: Chronic changes in bowel function, sexual dysfunction, low risk of pelvic fracture or secondary cancer.
patientEducation.safetyConsiderations: Meticulous perineal skin care (sitz baths, barrier creams). Reporting fever/chills immediately due to low blood counts. Importance of hydration. Low-residue diet to manage diarrhea.
patientEducation.patientResponsibilities: Attend daily RT, manage 5-FU pump as instructed, weekly labs and OTVs, report symptoms promptly.
patientEducation.medicationCompliance: Adherence to chemotherapy schedule. Proactive use of anti-diarrheals and skin care products.
